newsitem.title: USA: Boston Scientific backs '97 EPS forecast.
newsitem.headline: Boston Scientific backs '97 EPS forecast.

text.p: Boston Scientific Corp is comfortable with a 1997 earnings forecast of $1.90 per share, chief financial officer Larry Best said here Tuesday at a Piper Jaffray investors conference.
"I'm comfortable with $1.90" for 1997 earnings per share, Best said in an interview with Reuters.
The First Call consensus of 16 Wall Street analysts calls for the medical devices maker to earn $1.87 per share this year, compared to $1.54 per share in 1996.
Boston Scientific also is targeting a gross profit margin for the year of more than 72 percent, Best said.
"We're striving for north of 72," he said. "Last year was about 72 and then we dropped down into 71. Now, by the end of the year, we'll be safely over 72, approaching 73 percent."

After a flurry of acquisitions that caused revenues to explode to about $1.5 billion last year from one-third of that just five years earlier, Boston Scientific in the first quarter of this year saw profit margins and earnings growth slip.
As Wall Street concerns grew about the company's ability to control costs while integrating new businesses, the share price declined.
At mid-Tuesday, shares were trading 59-7/8, up 1-7/8, well off a 12-month high of 71-1/2.
In his presentation to investors on Tuesday, Best said Boston Scientific this year will begin to realize gains from costly investments in new employees and plant capacity made since 1996.
Boston Scientific will report revenues of about $2 billion this year and have more than 11,000 employees by year-end, he said.
"We think our operating margins will be north of 30 percent and we think our net margins will be at 20 or better" this year, Best said.

"Over the next three years, we will grow higher than 20 percent top-line and we will grow bottom-line faster than that ... We gut-wise, see no reason why we can't grow this business 25 percent over the next three years," he said.
